I would treat the mesh screen itself with a bug barrier spray. 3-M Ultrathon spray would be a pick of mine, there are others too. Perimeter barrier systems such as Thermacell products are also effective. Put the mesh in a gallon zip-lock and fog it down good, a few times even. Couldn't hurt to use the same spray barrier to do your perimeter around your bunks too.That should at least discourage them from even landing on it, and you.

You can laugh but we take flea collars for dogs and keep one in our pocket and we also put one around our ankle. When we get out of the bed in the morning, we throw one in the sleeping bag as well. Have never had a problem with any of the bugs. Just make sure to "snap" the collar to activate it, some require a quick tug at both ends for them to work.

They were the worst I've ever seen in 15+ years for us on the English river. They were only around back at camp in the evening, but they made it impossible to sit out at night. Ultrathon was helpful, but not a complete deterrent.

I wouldn't spray anything on the screen that may dissolve it. Are they actually coming in thru the screen? Most of the campers use screening that is no-seeum proof. I found that my problem was not the screening but small openings around the canvas in the pop-up camper. Easily stuffed with a paper towel. I used to light an insect coil before bedtime and let it burn for a while before actually going to bed. This killed all the flying stuff before we settled in and didn't have to use the spray bombs. I learned to put the burning coil out before going to bed, as I used to wake up with a headache if I let it burn all nite, even if the screen was left open. Another bush trick is wear an old white dress shirt with long sleeves when out in the bush. Several benefits: white shirt is cool and the colour doesn't attract biting insects, insects can't penetrate the tight weave of the shirt, ladies think you are a rich executive, guides think you may be a big tipper, wife thinks you are going on a business trip. Tight Lines

We just got back from Minaki, and they were bad this year -- worst that I've ever seen them in 25+ years. I know it doesn't help much for a camper or while sleeping, but we found that sunscreen seemed to slow them down to the point that you could at least see them and flick them off before they bit while you were fishing. We sprayed the 4 corners of the windows in the cabin with a little Black Flag Insect Spray, and that seemed to keep them out of the cabin when we had the windows open. But I don't know if you'd be able to do that in your camper. Chuck
